reviewText: After hip replacement surgery I needed to get walking again but still was working on balance.The Nordic walking poles are just what I was looking for.  They are lightweight, easy to use and come with great instructions.I am very happy with them and getting out there walking again!!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have been walking the sandy and rocky trails here in Northern Nevada in order to build up my stamina after chemo and radiation Cancer treatment. It's definitely helped but I wanted to try strengthening my upper body, too. I've seen people walking with poles so bought a cheap set of trekking poles after doing some research on line. The trekking poles were a hindrance, not a help, and I quickly realized that the  descriptions about their use did not really describe what they were NOT good for, which is the kind of walking that I, and, I assume, most people, do for fun and exercise. In my walking I swing my arms, as runners realize is necessary for efficient technique. Trekking poles are meant to be kept in front of you to stabilize you when shuffling along in steep or very rocky or loose terrain or with a heavy backpack. They can be used to swing along side you but are not really meant or designed for that. Further research convinced me that Nordic poles were more in line with the kind of walking that I do. Further checking, including reading the reviews here, also convinced me that these poles were a "best buy" so I ordered them.I'm very happy with the poles and with the dealer. I received an e-mail asking me to provide my height, so that the pole length could be determined, almost instantaneously with the placing of my order. The poles were shipped the same day and I received them very quickly without expedited shipping.As someone who Cross Country skied quite a bit in the past I believed that I wouldn't have too much trouble picking up the basic technique and I was right. The poles came with two 8&1/2"X11" sheets of paper with printed set of instructions which described the technique. It is very close to Cross country ski poling from which it derives. One thing the instructions emphasize is not gripping the handles of the ski poles but allowing them to swing free tethered by the patented glove-like strap. After using the poles for awhile, I realized that while Cross country skiing I did grip the poles too much and having these straps on Cross country ski poles would make them much easier to use effectively for skiing.The poles also came with a DVD and I was excited to receive it because it's always easier to learn when you can see a proper example of what's being taught. However, the DVD was a disappointment. Rather than being an instructional DVD it was really a promotional DVD with only a very small section on instruction on proper technique which wasn't very well done. After all of the emphasis in the written materials on not holding on to the handles of the poles, the beginners shown do hold on to their poles. The DVD shows a very fit woman with the firmest Gluteous Maximus in all of Christendom springing around like a Gazelle or a Mountain Sheep in the Rockies. It's nice to see the potential of the poles but little time is shown as to how to develop it. There are many videos on-line showing how to use Nordic style poles, although they do show varying versions of "Nordic walking", so while they do not vary very much it can be somewhat confusing. However, they do give you enough information so that you get the general idea and you can experiment with the variations to see which work best for you.The poles in actual use: As I said, the patented glove/strap works really well and one does not need to grasp the handles. However, the strap does rub my hand at the base of my forefinger where it meets the crotch with my thumb. Also I found that while the "letting the poles swing free technique" works well on open flat ground, it needs to be modified when using a narrow path bordered by rocks and bushes. In that case more effort is required to move the poles over obstacles and one does need to hold on to the the handles with one's fingers to do so. Further, the total release use of the poles allows them to drag along the ground. Dragging across snow has no side affects, dragging across stoney and rocky ground is noisy. Just planting the poles on rocky ground is noisy enough, so idyllic solitude is disturbed by using the poles and my accompanying wife complained about the noise.Another problem that I had was that the poles when not gripped and swinging forward would sometimes land in line with my feet so that I would stumble over them.The one really annoying problem is how difficult and time consuming it is to remove the straps and the poles if you need to use your hands for anything. The click out straps would be much nicer to have. I don't know if they are available on one piece non-metal poles but if they are, I would recommend those over these. They may not be as adjustable as are these straps but there are no instructions that come with these poles as to how to lengthen and shorten the straps and I'd rather pay for a second set of straps, if I needed them for wearing gloves, in exchange for the convenience of easily freeing one's hands.The fact that the poles are one piece definitely makes them lighter and stronger which will be important when the stage is reached that one really pushes off them with one's arms. Not being metal means that they are not as noisy in use.I have one complaint with the product. Otherwise it seems to be ideal. I do agree with Rebecca's concern. Before I purchased these poles I read all the reviews and I did not understand her concern. I now do. As I state above, it is a problem to use your hands to take a drink from a bottle, blow your nose, pull stickers from your dog, pick up dog poop, etc. because removing the poles is not easy.My only other complaint is that I wish that there was a more comprehensive, detailed instruction DVD provided showing how to use the poles in a wide range of terrain situations.

reviewText: This is a sturdy product.  I use them when walking in the woods or hiking.  I would recommend them if you walk on rough terrain.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I purchased these poles for my 75 year old mother.  She was able to use them right away without having to follow any difficult instructions.  Her 70ish walking partner saw them and had to have a pair, as well.  My mom absolutely loves them.  She says they help her stand taller and she really feels that she is exerting more energy when she is walking.  I would recommend these poles to anyone.

reviewText: I bought these - yes, two, a set for me and a set for my best friend - I will have to come back later to let everyone know how these "poles" worked for us - we can use a little more exercise, you know.  Nordic promises much; we will see . . .
summary: I will have to let you know . . .

reviewText: After having bought (2) pairs of twist-locking poles that didn't last; because once the poles fell, they were then rendered useless.  I ordered the REAL NORDIC WALKING POLES.  These one piece poles cut to your height specification are great.  Having mobility issues the other poles were not safe for me. These help me walk straighter and taller for a longer length of time. These poles are lightweight yet sturdy and durable.  The price is good because they will last.  They arrived on time as stated.  The individual that took my height info at Real Nordic Walking Poles was courteous and professional.Would highly recommend whether you have walking issues or not.  Great exercise.

reviewText: My wife absolutely enjoys the quality , fit, and ease of these poles.  The owner was very quick to contact us regarding size.  The hand grips are comfortable and quick to adapt to.  Having watched other hikers and the problems they face with adjustable poles, I am glad we purchased these fine poles.
summary: The best there is for the price !
